thread.title: Couple have been taking photos in photobooths every year for sixteen years | Metro News
thread.title_full: Couple have been taking photos in photobooths every year for sixteen years | Metro News

author: Hattie Gladwell For Metro.Co.Uk
title: Couple have been taking photos in photobooths every year for sixteen years | Metro News
text:
Hattie Gladwell for Metro.co.uk Tuesday 28 Feb 2017 12:55 pm (Picture: Cover Images) I refuse to be ashamed of relying on my partner for money 
39-year-old Giles Paley-Phillips and his now wife, Michelle, 35, decided to document their love using the public passport photograph machines back in 2000, when the pair began dating having known each other since childhood. 
They had grown up in the same small town and had grown up together, but had only bumped into one another as adults again in 2000 at Brighton station – when Giles was 23 and Michelle, 18. This picture was taken back in 2000 (Picture: Cover Images) 
Giles’ first thoughts as he looked at Michelle were ‘Wow!’ 
By 2002, Giles, a children’s author and Michelle, a designer and store planner, were a married couple. 
And, with two years of photobooth photos already under their belts, they decided to keep the tradition going – to watch their lives unfold and develop as they grew older. By 2002, the pair were wed (Picture: Cover Images) 
‘I loved having a picture with my ‘wife’. We felt as if we’d been together for many years and knew it was right,’ explained Giles. 
The pictures continued as the years went on, but according to Giles, 2006’s image will always remain the most ‘momentous photobooth moment’, as they’d just found out that Michelle was three months pregnant. 
Giles said: ‘She had terrible morning sickness that day. I think we both knew life would never be the same again.’ 
The last picture of the pair as a single couple came just before their son, Elijah, was born in 2007. The pair gave birth to their son, Elijah, in 2007 (Picture: Cover Images) 
The couple ran off into a booth outside a supermarket knowing they were soon to become parents, to take one last photo on their own for the photobooth album. 
Later, in 2009, Giles and Michelle gave birth to their second child, Sonny, who was able to join the family portrait alongside Elijah. Though Giles admits, it wasn’t easy. 
He said: ‘The photobooth was in a post office and I remember trying to squeeze two growing children into the booth and realising there would be less and less space each year as they got bigger and that one day they would be grown men like me.’ They were a family of four by 2009! (Picture: Cover Images) 
By 2012, the effects of having two active young sons were visible, as Giles says he finally let his grey hair come through. 
The family say they will continue the photobooth tradition as Elijah, now 10 and Sonny, 8, grow up – although Giles says: ‘It’s getting harder to find photo booths, they are becoming more scarce.’ 
While they will continue to hunt for photobooths to keep up tradition, Giles and Michelle will also spend time looking back on the photos they have already saved. They say that having looked back on the album already, they’ve noticed how drastically things have changed – yet they’re happier than ever. Here they are, all grown up! (Picture: Cover Images) 
Looking back, Giles said: ‘I think we both know we are different people, but the same somehow. My feelings for Michelle are just the same, perhaps stronger than ever. 
‘Our favourite picture is the one where the four of us are in it for the first time, our family complete.’
